title: Is a ruling granting a motion under CCP 664.6 the same as winning a judgment?
question: With the help of an attorney, I sued one of my suppliers (I run a wholesale business) and we ended up settling. The defendant then breached the settlement, so my attorney filed a motion under CCP 664.6 to enforce the settlement agreement. The judge granted our motion.
answers: No. You now need to have the court (i.e., the judge) sign a Judgment and have the Clerk enter the Judgment in the court records.

You should probably ask the Judge sign a document entitled a "Judgment" and It needs to say Judgment is entered in favor of XX and against YY in the amount of XX. If the judgment is against more than one person, it should specify whether it is joint and several or XX just against one and XX against the other. Hopefully the Order specifies these things and you can copy the order. If you do it yourself, be patient and polite and if the judge asks you to do it over, do it over per the judge's instructions.

The judgment is a crucial document, It is the thing you spent all that money litigating for and it is what you will use to collect the money. It ends the case so it very hard to correct if it is wrong.

Call the judge's clerk and ask what the judge needs you to do to get judgment entered. You may need a motion but I think the judge will sign it because he granted the motion per 664.6.

Didn't the judge mention getting judgment entered at the last OSC ?

The judge's clerk will likely then file the judgment for you and give you an endorsed copy or you may have to file it in the clerk's office.

Then you serve a copy of of the judgment with another document entitled notice of entry of judgment. That starts the time for appeal running. File the Notice of entry also.

If you get the judgment wrong, it is HARD or impossible to fix so be careful. This is not rocket science but you can screw it up easily. I would spend that last $500 or so and have your lawyer prepare the judgment and get it entered.

Good luck

Greg G
I agree with other counsel, you would need to have the judgment recorded by the Clerk of the Court.
You need to have the judgment recorded by the Clerk of the court.

Your attorney should have prepared a form of judgment that would have been submitted with the motion to enforce the settlement agreement. Check the court's files, there may already be a judgment signed. If so, then all you need is a copy.
You need to get the judgment signed by the judge. There is a judicial council form for a judgment that you can get at the court's website. Then you will have to enforce the judgment. You were probably a little premature in terminating your attorney. You should have at least waited until the judgment was processed.
Talk to an attorney.
